https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

The documentation details are mentioned as a link on the readme file as given below. 
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/blob/master/README.md

Besides the above link, the raw format of documentation is also available in the vignettes folder.
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/blob/master/vignettes/introduction_to_conjurer.Rmd
documentation_interface_justification: This information is documented in detail within the "introduction to conjurer" vignette. The link to this vignette is added as a link in the readme file
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: There is only one version released so far. The next version will be set up as a separate branch and then released subsequently.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Versioning follows the principles mentioned in Hadley Wickham's book. Currently, there is only one version and hence this line item does not apply.
version_semver_justification: This will be considered when new versions are developed
version_tags_justification:
The first release is tagged as a release and can be seen at the following url
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/releases
release_notes_justification: This is the first version and hence no details in terms of versioning is released.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There are no bugs or known vulnerabilities in the code. I have used Travis and codacy and have not noticed any such issues come up
report_tracker_justification:
The following url shows the issues.
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/issues
report_process_justification:
The following URL gives the details on submitting bugs and enhancement requests
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
report_responses_justification:
There have been no bugs reported so far. As for 2 enhancement request, I have responded to them in detail as given below
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/issues/17
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/issues/10
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/issues/12
enhancement_responses_justification:
I have responded to the issues in a timely manner as given below
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/issues/17
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/issues/10
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/issues/12
report_archive_justification:
The following URL has the historical information of closed issues as well
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
This project has automated security settings that allow GitHub to notify me of any issues. Following URL shows that status
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/network/alerts
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: All security vulnerability reports are public
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: All security vulnerability reports are public and there have been no such reports so far.
build_justification:
The software can be rebuilt using the files shared in the repository. The Rproj file at the given URL helps in running the same
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/blob/master/conjurer.Rproj
build_common_tools_justification:
devtools is used for the build and is mentioned clearly towards the end of the following file
https://github.com/SidharthMacherla/conjurer/blob/master/conjurer.Rproj
test_justification: This package generates synthetic data and hence example codes as part of man and vignette files perform this testing in Rcmd. There is no need for any further tests at this point in time

This package generates synthetic data and hence example codes as part of man and vignette files perform this testing in Rcmd. There is no need for any further tests at this point in time

warnings_strict_justification: The source code is built using R CMD and there were no errors/warnings/notes. Additionally, Travis CI was used and there were no errors/warnings/notes.

name: NOC
description:
Features:

Fault Management

Root Cause Analysis, topology correlation, escalation. Active probing and passive alarm condition detection in syslog and SNMP traps.


Performance Management

Flexible metrics collection via SNMP and CLI. Long-term metrics storage. Automatic configuration of dashboards. Complex threshold control with window functions.


Inventory

Centralized database of physical and logical resources. Tracks physical assets like chassis and modules. Tracks logical resources (IP, VLAN, Phone Numbers) usage as well. IP address planning via IPAM.


Discovery

Sophisticated multi-protocol network topology discovery. Configuration and resource usage discovery.


Vendor-agnostic

Breaking the vendor locks with 80+ of supported vendors. Adding new vendors and platforms on daily routine basis.


LargeScale

Starting from simple single-node installation and up to clusters controlling world’s largest networks with 300k+ of objects.


Integration

ETL interface allows to import data from existing systems. DataStream API and NBI interfaces provide services to other system.


Big Data

Introduces Big Data analysis to the Network Management. Builtin analytics database and provided BI tools allows to access magic
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.

name: temper
description: A blazingly simple Fahrenheit to Celcius converter
description_good_justification: https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/README.md Describes the purpose of the program and how to build and install it.
interact_justification: The project uses Github to report bugs and feature requests via its issue functionality.  https://github.com/sramsay/temper/issues
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: The complete text of GPL-3.0 is in the root directory of the project (as LICENSE), and viewable online at <https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: The basic documentation for this software is in the README.md file.
documentation_interface_justification: The external interface of this project is described in the README.md file.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: There is a development branch ("develop") for interim development from which release branches are created.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: Every release is tagged. See https://github.com/sramsay/temper/tags for a list of tags.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/ChangeLog.md
release_notes_vulns_justification: We have not detected any publicly known vulnerabilities, though we intend to document any such problems in the release notes: https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/ChangeLog.md
report_tracker_justification: The project uses GitHub for reporting issues: https://github.com/sramsay/temper/issues
report_process_justification: This project uses GitHub's issue tracker: https://github.com/sramsay/temper/issues
report_archive_justification: The project uses Github's issue tracker at https://github.com/sramsay/wwo/issues, which archives and allows for searching.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: This project has no known vulnerabilities. However, future vulnerabilities would be reported in the https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/README.md file and in the release notes https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/ChangeLog.md  when the problem is resolved.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: We have not received any vulnerability reports for this project.
build_justification: This project uses Meson and Ninja for builds, and contains all the necessary configuration files for creating the binary application from source.
test_justification: The project is tested with a unit test suite (https://github.com/sramsay/temper/tree/master/test) which is part of the project. The test suite is released under the same license. The test suite uses Catch (https://github.com/philsquared/Catch) which is released under the Boost Software License 1.0, and Bats (https://github.com/sstephenson/bats) which is under an MIT license.
test_invocation_justification: There seems to be a bug in meson that is preventing "ninja check" from finding the appropriate script for running the cli tests, but that is the goal.  There's a workaround in place for the moment that allows the user to run the tests using an ordinary Makefile (make check).
warnings_strict_justification: The project builds with a wide variety of warning flags (-Wall -Winvalid-pch -Wnon-virtual-dtor -Wextra -Wpedantic) in both debug and release mode.
know_secure_design_justification: Stephen Ramsay is the primary developer. He has over twenty years of software development experience, and strives to adhere to the relevant principles.  The software is also routinely checked for common vulnerabilities using https://lgtm.com/projects/g/sramsay/temper/?mode=list as part of the continuous integration process.
static_analysis_justification: clang-tidy and Cppcheck are run all commits.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: The code is constantly checked using clang-tidy, and with Cppcheck (on every commit) through Codacy, as well as lgtm (daily, on most recent commit).
dynamic_analysis_justification: Valgrind is run on all commits.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Valgrind is run regularly, and regularly fuzzed using iFuzz (https://github.com/google/syzkaller/tree/master/pkg/ifuzz)
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: This logic of this program is far too small to warrant the use of assertions, though the opportunity may arise.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: This project uses Travis-CI for continuous integration (https://travis-ci.org/sramsay/temper)
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
installation_common_justification: GNU Make provides install and uninstall capabilities.
code_of_conduct_justification: Code of Conduct based on Contributor Covenant 2.0: https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
documentation_quick_start_justification: The project's README serves this function: https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/README.md
documentation_current_justification: The (entirely manageable) documentation for this project is regularly reviewed.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: The hosting site (GitHub) supports, with exceptions, most of the provisons in section 508 of the U.S. Rehabilitation Act of 1973.  temper itself is a command-line program, and can easily be used with assistive devices like screen readers.
sites_password_security_justification: The project does not store passwords or use any authentication.
maintenance_or_update_justification: All previous releases are available at https://github.com/sramsay/temper/releases
coding_standards_justification: Coding standards are identified in the CONTRIBUTING document as generally conforming to the Google C++ Style Guide: https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html
coding_standards_enforced_justification: Coding standards are enforced using clang-format.
build_standard_variables_justification: Meson automatically reads user environment variables relevant to the build, and none of these variables are overridden by our build system.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Ninja automatically logs debugging and installation information, and the level of detail can be controlled by the user.
build_non_recursive_justification: There are no cross-dependencies in this system.
installation_standard_variables_justific: So far as I am aware, Ninja honors the POSIX conventions.
installation_development_quick_justifica: The build and installation system both use standard tools, and all build scripts are part of the project.  The necessary tools for building the project are widely available through package managers.
external_dependencies_justification: All external dependencies are listed in the README: https://github.com/sramsay/temper/blob/master/README.md
dependency_monitoring_justification: We review the code whenever dependencies are updated.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Meson can enforce particular versions of dependencies, as well as minimum versions.
interfaces_current_justification: The project does not use any deprecated (or non-FLOSS) APIs.
test_policy_mandated_justification: This is explained in the CONTRIBUTING document.
signed_releases_justification: Releases and commits are signed, see https://github.com/sramsay/temper/releases. The public key is linked in the README file.
version_tags_signed_justification: A tag is created for every release, and all releases are signed.
